summary: This is a memorandum opinion and order by Judge Alison J. Nathan denying Ghislaine Maxwell's motion to modify a protective order. Maxwell sought to use discovery materials from her criminal case in related civil proceedings. The court found her arguments insufficient to establish good cause for modification, though it permitted her to share specific, already-public information about grand jury subpoenas with the relevant civil courts under seal.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case who filed a motion to modify a protective order to use discovery materials in civil cases.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge who authored this opinion and order, ruling on Maxwell's motion.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the subject of a grand jury investigation into him and his possible co-conspirators.

connections.description: The document references a grand jury investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and his possible co-conspirators, with Maxwell being the defendant in the related criminal case.

events.title: Maxwell Files Sealed Motion
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell filed a sealed letter motion seeking to modify the protective order to use criminal discovery in civil cases.

events.title: Protective Order Entered
events.description: The court entered a protective order in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell, restricting the use of discovery materials to the defense of the criminal action.

events.title: Government Seeks Modification of Civil Orders
events.description: The government, ex parte and under seal, sought modification of civil protective orders to permit compliance with grand jury subpoenas issued in the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Courts Rule on Modification Requests
events.description: One court (Court-1) permitted the modification of a civil protective order to allow compliance with grand jury subpoenas, while another court (Court-2) did not.

events.title: Court Denies Maxwell's Motion
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issued an order denying Ghislaine Maxwell's motion to modify the protective order.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: Judge Alison J. Nathan denied Ghislaine Maxwell's request to modify a protective order, preventing her from using discovery from her criminal case in related civil proceedings.
The court found Maxwell's arguments for modification were 'vague, speculative, and conclusory' and failed to establish good cause.
The document reveals that grand jury subpoenas were issued to an entity (the 'Recipient') as part of an investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and his possible co-conspirators.
The government had previously sought, ex parte and under seal, to modify civil protective orders to obtain materials responsive to the grand jury subpoenas, with mixed results from different courts.

The court permitted Maxwell to share specific, already-public information about the grand jury subpoena process with the relevant civil courts under seal, and to make applications to unseal materials in those courts.
